since the lockdown but warned annual sales could plunge by % in a worst-case scenario as a result of the coronavirus outbreak..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: John Lewis reveals first stores to reopen doors on June

title: lockdown-reveals-success-efforts-help-rare-field-crickets
story: The coronavirus lockdown has halted efforts to help field crickets ndash but has helped scientists confirm that their bid to protect the rare insects is already working.Lockdown rules meant the RSPB had to abandon a final bid to translocate field crickets to restored habitat on two reserves, to help bolster new populations of the threatened species, the wildle charity said.But wardens carrying out fire and livestock checks at the Pulborough Brooks and Farnham Heath reserves this month heard field crickets singing at the release sites, a sign that previous releases have led to successful breeding.Any crickets, which have an annual le cycle, heard calling this year must be the offspring of insects released in previous years." srcset"https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    ea-e--d-bfdd.jpg w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    ea-e--d-bfdd.jpg w w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    ea-e--d-bfdd.jpg w w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    ea-e--d-bfdd.jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Field crickets were once the sound of summer but are now very rare And it was only because no new releases could take place this year, so no newly introduced crickets could be singing, that scientists could confirm that the previous translocations are working, the RSPB said.The insects were once the soundtrack to summer evenings, but numbers dropped to just  iniduals at a single location in the s in the face of changes to how land was managed and loss of their grassy heathland homes.Conservation work over the past  years has put them on the road to recovery, with populations in eight locations across Surrey, Sussex and Hampshire, but they are still one of the UKrsquos most threatened species.The RSPB and conservation agency Natural England have been working to boost populations of the crickets since April  as part of the National Lottery-funded Back From The Brink programme to help rare wildle.The scheme aims to establish a new colony at the Pulborough Brooks reserve in West Sussex and extend an existing colony at Farnham Heath in Surrey ndash with the RSPB now hailing the success of the scheme." srcset"https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    dadf-df-be--dcaffa.jpg w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    dadf-df-be--dcaffa.jpg w w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    dadf-df-be--dcaffa.jpg w w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    dadf-df-be--dcaffa.jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"The scheme aimed to establish a new colony at Pulborough Brooks RSPB reserve in West Sussex Using a technique known as ldquotickling with a blade of grass, experts encourage young field crickets, or nymphs hatching underground and beginning to emerge, out from their burrows so they can be caught and moved to new areas.The scheme allows youngsters from an established colony to be moved to a specially selected area where it is hoped a new colony will be formed.Conservationists say that creating new populations is vital as it reduces the risk of losing the entire species to a single catastrophe such as a fire.RSPB senior ecologist Jane Sears said: ldquoThere is something quite evocative about the soft chirping of a cricket on a warm summerrsquos evening.ldquoUnfortunately, with field crickets on the verge of extinction, we almost lost their song.ldquoSo it was with a heavy heart we cancelled our final chance to bolster the population with the Back From The Brink project, unsure of how our previous attempts to create new breeding sites had fared.ldquoThe news that our new colonies are doing well has given us hope the species can be brought back from the brink.ldquoWe have seen how, with the right conditions, the species can thrive.Although the Back From The Brink programme ends this year, the RSPB will continue to monitor field cricket populations..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Lockdown reveals success of efforts to help rare field crickets

title: covid-19-testing-centre-opening-former-power-station-site
story: The drive-through centre will be operated by the st Infantry Brigade which oversees the army reserve unitsin Scotland and will carry out tests on key workers from tomorrowto Monday with plans toagain in two weeksrsquo time.East Lothian Council confirmed it had made the site available as part of the UKGovernmentrsquos Covid- testing programme.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre since the start of April.The Cockenzie site, bought by the local authority from ScottishPower, is currently being marketed for economic investment.In preparation of the appointment-only testing unitrsquos opening, signs and cones have been put in place to direct drivers.The centre will re-open on Saturday, May , through to Monday, June , and is providing back-up support to a main testing centre at EdinburghAirport.Key workers who have symptoms, or have a member of their household displaying symptoms, can self-refer to the site through the UK Governmentrsquos online portal.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site while the facility is closed.The council said it expects the unit to operate as a self-contained, drivethrough facility.People will remain in their vehicle while being tested.It is not known how many tests can be carried out at the site each day.Tom Reid, the councilrsquos head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel.ldquoThis facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-. East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the move to open the centre at Cockenzie.He said: ldquoI have been calling on the Scottish Government to follow the World Health Organisationrsquos advice and ramp up the amount of testing we are doing for over a month now, so I welcome this new centre in Cockenzie and hope it will mean local key workers do not have to travel so far to access a test.ldquoA signicant increase in testing capacity will be essentialthe Scottish Governmentrsquos plans for testing, tracing and isolating are to be successful and this centre will contribute to the expansion needed.The move was also welcomed by local community councils.Bryan Hickman, chairperson of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, said: ldquoWe are pleased that the site is being used for a testing unit. It seems very suitable and hopefully it will help in getting this terrible virus under control.Brian Weddell, chairperson of Prestonpans Community Council, said: ldquoThe former power station site at Preston Links is an ideal location for a Covid testing site for East Lothian. It is remote enough from local communities with plenty of space to ensure government distancing regulations are maintained.The drive-through testing centres are available to people who live less than  minutes drive from them and are in addition to NHS Scotland testing.Scottish Government guidelines on who can apply for a test at the UK Government mobile testing centres are on their website.For a full list of those eligible to go bit.ly csBii Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via the self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stationrsquos famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September , two years after it had closed.

title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: blow-musselburgh-racing-hopes
story: Bosses at the East Lothian track had hoped to hold races behind closed doors on Saturday, June , as the industry looks to restart under restrictions.Groundstaff at thetownrsquos award-winning racecourse, who have been furloughed, were expected to temporarily resume work this month to prepare the track for the anticipated fixture.And East Lothian MP Kenny Macaskill added his voice to a letter to Scottish sports minister Joe FitzPatrick, MSP, urging him to allow Scotlands racecourse to host fixtures as soon as possible.Bill Farnsworth, general manager, was due on Monday to bring a report to MRACwhich oversees course governance, setting out hopes of a restart in early June.However, the BHA released its provisional fixture list for the restart yesterdayand all the racing proposed is in England.The BHA said thatGovernment restrictions eased at the end of the month, it intended to start behind-closed-door racing at Newcastle on June  with  meetings at seven tracks planned for the first eight days of racing.After a single meeting on June  there will be at least two meetings each day with three ndash one each in the north, south and midlands ndash scheduled from Saturday June  to Monday June  inclusive.There will be no regional restrictions on runners competing at any meetings.Mr Farnsworth had hoped Musselburgh would be allowed to take part in the behind closed doors fixtures in June after pointing out how the industry was ready to go.He said: ldquoIf horseracing resumes in June, we hope to stage Musselburghrsquos scheduled fixture on Saturday,June  butthe advice is that June is too early to stage horseracing in Scotland, we will wait until for the appropriate time and for the greenlight from the UK and Scottish Governments.Horse-racing ed in France this week giving hope to trainers that Britain will not be far behind.A joint letter to Scottish Sports Minister Joe Fitzpatrick, MSP, from East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill and MPs Allan Dorans, Angela Crawley and Pete Wishart, who represent racecourses in Hanmilton, Ayr and Perth urges a quick restart to racing when safe to do so.It says: ldquoRacing finds itself in a unique position compared to other Scottish sports in that our equine athletes, cherished so highly by those in the industry, have remained in training during thepandemic and will therefore be able to come back on shorter notice than the human athletes inother sports.ldquoWhen it is safe to do so, ato racing is the best way of getting the economic cogs of theindustry turning once more, and kickstart the benefits to the Scottish economy that horseracingbrings, even in a behind closed doors environment.ldquoTherefore, we ask that you please accelerateyour talks with Scottish racing to ensure that a risk managedcan take place as soon aspossible and that ato racing behind closed doors in Scotland does not get unduly delayedcompared to the rest of the United Kingdom.

title: new-town-top-low-carbon-location
story: The local authority has lodged its vision for the future with Scottish Ministers as they prepare to create a new National Policy Framework .But it has warned its ambitions must not be sacriced in a rush to kickstart the economy as the nation comes out of lockdown.In an opening statement to their submission, officials expressed concern that new developments may lose sight of the long-term ambition they have for the county.They tell the Scottish Government: ldquoThe current challenges brought about by coronavirus may have lasting effects on the economy.ldquoWhile demand for new development will , it is important that, in the short term, standards in new development are not prejudiced to stimulate growth.ldquoThe ambitions around climate change, ecology, health and well-being, equality, connectivity, inclusive growth and place-making remain.East Lothian Council wants the National Development designation given to the former Cockenzie Power Station site in previous frameworks to be expanded to include the new town of Blindwells which is underway on nearby land, in the new NPF.The council believes that National Development status for the wider area including nearby Blindwells would support ambitions for sustainable growth and an emerging vision for the area to be an influential, innovative, healthy and carbon neutral location.And they say the larger site could become one of Scotlands top ten low carbon locations.While the boundaries of the area are still to be finalised it could stretch out to cover existing communities of Tranent, Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry.Councillor Norman Hampshire, East Lothian Council spokesperson for Environment, said it was important the county continued to plan for the future during the Covid- outbreak.And he said it was important the ambitions set out before the lockdown continued to be at the heart of decisions made.He said: ldquoWe are ambitious for East Lothian and want to see it remain as a great place in which to live and work, which is well connected with good employment opportunities and sustainability principles at its heart.The local authority has asked Scottish Ministers to designate an area known as The Blindwells, Cockenzie and Climate Change Zone, as a National Development.Councillor Hampshire said: ldquoWe want to see the new settlement at Blindwells developed as a fantastic community in which to live and work.ldquoIt should be a zero emissions community embracing climate change objectives and embracing blue green infrastructure and bioersity.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site offers signicant opportunity in terms of economic development and employment and work continues to understand its potential.ldquoIn our proposal for a National Development, we are suggesting that a Climate Change Zone is created between these sites, and including parts of, neighbouring communities and sites.ldquoWe believe this wider area, part of the former East Lothian coalfield, could be one of Scotlandrsquos top  locations for low carbon, sustainable inclusive growth and we are determined to grasp the opportunity.ldquoWe are making our case in a submission to the Scottish Government and will be carrying out public engagement on the extent of our vision for the area in due course.

title: edf-donates-3-000-face-masks-crossreach
story: CrossReach, which provides social care services on behalf of the Church of Scotland, has received , face masks from EDF Energy, operators of Torness Power Station.The masks will be used to ensure that staff and residents are protected during the Covid- outbreak.Torness Power Station, near Dunbar, along with its sister station in North Ayrshire and EDFrsquos office in East Kilbride, have each given , masks.CrossReach previously had a facility on Dunbarrsquos Bayswell Road, before it moved to Aldhammer House, Prestonpans.Elspeth McPheat, one of CrossReachrsquos care home managers, said: ldquoIt is amazing how kind and thoughtful people are being.ldquoIt means so much to know that, as social care workers, you are loved and cared for by others when you are loving and caring for those in your care.Rob Guyler, EDFrsquos chief financial officer, said: ldquoWe want to be able to do our bit to support people in the community during these dficult times so we are happy to make this donation.

title: praise-music-teachers-noteworthy-contribution
story: Nicola Presavage, from Haddington, an instrumental co-ordinator in music percussion at Loretto School, Musselburgh, is on furlough leave.For the past three weeks, she has been making face masks and headbands, free of charge, for nurses, care home workers, shop assistants, cleaners and even an offshore medic!The headbands are for people who find wearing face masks on their ears uncomfortable, with more than  already distributed.They work by looping the elastic or ties from masks around the button of the headband instead of around the ears. The buttons are in a position just behind the ear.Mrs Presavage has also issued  washable cloth-made face masks to recipients.Most of the masks and headbands have been collected from her house and, in keeping with social distancing, she has clipped them to her fence in sealed bags for people to collect. She has also posted out some orders.Many people in the community have been supporting the initiative by dropping off spare fabric or buttons they had at home.Mrs Presavage said: ldquoHearing tales from key workers dealing with all of this from the frontline is quite harrowing and puts everything into perspective.She added: ldquoI originally put a post on Facebook and asked for anyone looking for one to get in touch. As long as I am on furlough I am happy to keep making them. Elastic is becoming more dficult to source though.Her initiative has taken off, so she is now requesting pound. per mask to cover the cost of materials after running out of her original supply of fabric.She isnrsquot taking any more orders at the moment due to a backlog but is hoping to do so again soon.A Loretto School spokesperson added: ldquoHer contribution to helping those on the frontline is amazing ndash wersquore so proud.Mrs Presavage can be contacted via the Haddington Community Council Facebook page.

title: tributes-paid-british-legion-loses-two-members
story: Chairman of the branch Edward OrsquoConnor died on May , at Tranent Care Home, where he was being cared for after suffering a minor stroke.Mr OrsquoConnor, , was described by branch secretary Andrew Davie as an active member who was always involved in ious s in the club, often officiating in sports and competitions such as golf, bowling, fishing, dominoes and darts.Mr Davie said Mr OrsquoConnor had also been the first to join a recently created area of the British Legion, Edinburgh, Lothians and Borders. He carried out his duties as chairman all over Scotland representing the new area.Mr Davie said: ldquoHe will be missed by all the members, as he was always in the club. His long service in the RAF, home and abroad will be remembered.Mr OrsquoConnor leaves one daughter, Sharon.The branch also lost management committee member Alistair Marshall in March.Mr Marshall was well known for collecting thousands of pounds for Poppyscotland and acting as standard bearer for the Royal British Legionat ceremonial events.Mr Marshall, who was , served in the Royal Engineers.Mr Davie said: ldquoAlistair was involved in doing many things when on the committee. As a dedicated doorman at the weekend he made sure everybody behaved themselves. At other events he was a collector for Poppyscotland, especially during Armistice Remembrance, raising many thousands of pounds.ldquoHe was also a standard bearer, carrying out his duties at ceremonial events for RBL and at the passing away of our many comrades, at the graveside and crematoriums.ldquoTo his we Sylvia and stepchildren Karen and Bob, we send our deepest sympathy. He will be sadly missed by all his comrades.

title: fundraiser-memory-life-soul-party-ben
story: Ben Forsyth passed away in July,  after being forced to give up the sport he loved in , following a diagnosis of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathyndash a progressive and incurable disease of the heart muscles.His friend Katie Murray, a -year-old nurse, is hoping to raise funds through a challenge which encourages people to participate in health and fitness activities during May, June and July.This month people are being urged to walk  miles which is roughly .km a day or , steps.In the month of June, , squats shouldbe undertaken, with , burpeescompleted in July.Money raised will go to Cardiac Risk in the Young , which offers cardiac screening to young people, in memory of Ben who passed away after a sudden cardiac event.Following a cardiac screening in , an irregularity was discovered in his heart which led to him being referred to the NHS.In May , he started to develop breathing problems during races and a further MRI scan revealed he had ARVC.A former Musselburgh Grammar School pupil and member of Edinburgh Road Clubcycling club, he won the British Youth Circuit Race Championship in  at Blackpool.A member of Spokes race team, he also raced with Olympic cyclinglegend Sir Chris Hoy at the opening the Sir Chris Hoy Velodrome in Glasgow.Katie, who works in the Department of Clinical Neurosciences at the Western General Hospital in Edinburgh, hopes the fitness challenge will bring some fun to lockdown and encourage people to get moving and join in with their friends and family.She said: ldquoI think this will help keep people motivated to keep active during lockdown as it gives us all a goal to work towards whilst raising money for a brilliant cause.ldquoCRY is a fantastic charity that offers cardiac screening to all young people between the ages of  and , and helps to detect cardiac abnormalities in people within this age group. So far, CRY have been able to screen , young people across the UK. Thanks to fundraising efforts from Benrsquos family and friends, this is a number that we hope will continue to rise.Katie, who knew Ben since P at Stoneyhill Primary School, added: ldquoFor every month successfully completed, we ask for a donation of pound. If not completed then we would appreciate any donation at all.Mutual friends are getting involved to complete the challenge and Katie added: ldquoSome are making adjustments to the challenges so that they are able to participate and complete the challenge in a way that enables them to do so, and I would strongly recommend this for anyone who wishes to take part and join us.Katie, of Denholm Road, and Ben, whose family live in the Clayknowes area, both went to Musselburgh Grammar School and lived one street apart.She said: ldquoWe were close friends both in and out of school and shared lots of mutual friends. Following school, we both went to Edinburgh University where Ben studied geography and I studied nursing. Although we both studied dferent courses, I still saw Ben on a regular basis as our group of school friends has remained close.ldquoHe was always the le and soul of the party and had an infectious energy that followed him everywhere he went. A great person to be around and an even better friend, so kind and generous. Even when he was living le to the full, he always had time for other people, be it his friends or family.To donate, go to Virgin Money Giving at https:uk.virginmoneygiving KatieMurray

title: new-racecourse-operators-getting-ready-take-reins
story: Delays to finalising a deal between East Lothian Council and Chester Race Company meant that the planned handover at the end of March this year did not go ahead.However during an online meeting today of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee , which currently oversees the governance of the course, members were told Chester will take over "no later than" June .Reading a joint statement on behalf of the council and Chester, the local authoritys legal adviser Carlo Grilli said talks between the two parties continued positively.He said: "We continue to work positively with Chester and both parties are working on details of the contract to allow a transfer date of no later than  June."Mr Grilli declined to discuss details of the contract during the public part of the meeting which was held via Skype after he was quizzed about prize money and priority races commitments agreed between the council and Chester.The racecourse was managed until  by Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee, which was made up of three elected East Lothian councillors and two members of Lothians Racing Syndicate.However, after an independent review called into question the governance of that committee amid claims of toxic relationships between members, the council replaced it with MRAC,which has four councillors and two racing experts on it, and agreed to find a third-party operator to take over its management.Chester was announced as the preferred operator in October last year and discussions over the details of the -year lease have been ongoing.Delays to the initialy March handover were put down to the coronavirus crisis.Councillor Stuart Currie, MRAC member, welcomed news that a June deadline is being worked towards.He said: "I think I speak on behalf of everyone when I sayI am really pleased we seem to be moving towards a conclusion."

title: housing-given-go-ahead-wallyford
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee approved plans via a video conference this week for  to  houses at the south and east of the village and on land at neighbouring Dolphingstone.Planning permission in principle for the development was initially granted nearly three years ago by the committee against the recommendation of their officers.This week they were asked to agree to approve it on the understanding that developers pay pound,, towards additional accommodation at the new Wallyford Primary and Nursery and the provision of a new Musselburgh secondary school.They were also be asked to contribute over pound, towards road improvements at nearby Old Craighall and agreed developers would pay just under pound, to Network Rail to allow s in East Lothian to be extended to allow longer trains.During the meeting it was revealed the council has bought land for a new secondary school just north of the housing site.The plans take the total number of new homes approved for the Wallyford area alongside the ongoing St Clements Wells site, to about ,.A report to councillors nxt week will say that an agreement on developers contributions between council officers and developers East Lothian Development Ltd have not been agreed and the figures required have now been revised as time has passed.The proposed development at the site will also include community facilities with a possible local supermarket and several commercial units included in the plans.

title: seamstress-schoolgirl-sews-masks-ve-day-bunting
story: Niamh McMath, , a primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School, is making the masks using a sewing machine she received for Christmas one year, after completing sewing classes.Mum Marie, who lives with Niamh on North Seton Park, said: ldquoShe is making them herself as she got sewing lessons. She just loved them and then got a sewing machine for Christmas.ldquoShersquos really good at it and has made lots of things since the schools have been off shersquos made me a peg bag and a little pouch that can go around my wrist to store my phone in when Irsquom out walking the dog.ldquoI donrsquot know how she does it all.Niamhrsquos younger sister Orla helps by cutting the material and preparing it for production.The material she is using to make them was bought for her by friends and family when she received her sewing machine.A lack of elastic means Niamh is using string, which she finger-knits to make the loops that secure the mask around the wearerrsquos ears.Marie said: ldquoShe saw something in the news about people starting to making their own masks and also the schools making things like visors and she was inspired by that and thought she could make them herself.Niamh sourced a pattern she could refer to and, as there is no printer in the house, drew out the pattern herself.Marie said: ldquoShe made the first one all by herself and when she knew the process enough she explained it to my younger daughter.In about two weeks, Niamh has made roughly  masks, handing them out to friends and family who live nearby.Marie said: ldquoShersquos really talented at it.ldquoA couple of people we have given them to have offered some money but we said to donate it to charity.ldquoItrsquos a challenge to fit things in around school work.ldquoShe made bunting for the front of the house for VE Day, so that took up a bit of time, but she is back to making masks as usual.

title: pipe-major-joins-ve-day-celebrations
story: The tune is traditionally played at the end of a battle.Other members of North Berwick Pipe Band played the same music at their front doors at the same time, while one played at the Dirleton war memorial.North Berwick Pipe Band membersrsquo lessons have been continuing online during lockdown, while several pipers have been playing daily at pm at home as part of a lockdown challenge.On Thursday evenings, several pipers and drummers have been playing regularly outside their houses at pm during the weekly Clap for Carersrsquo tribute.

title: letter-week-welcoming-wildflowers
story: Left free from mowing and spraying, the countyrsquos green spaces have prolerated with daisies, dandelions, campion, cow parsley and many other colourful and native species.At a sad time, this resurgence has been a cheerful sight. It has also provided vital habitats and sustenance for the pollinators our planet needs to survive.It is crucial that we provide homes for nature: bees, butterflies, birds, bats and many other types of wildle are all in sharp decline.If East Lothian Councilresumes its policy of regularly spraying pavements, roads and grass edges with glyphosate weedkiller, it will damage not just the plants it is targeting but our wider ecosystem.Spraying weeds removes homes for pollinators and wildle. Bees and other pollinators are vital to our crops, our gardens, our countryside and our planet.Glyphosate wipes out insect populations, pollutes our waterways and ends up poisoning our fish.Defenders of glyphosate point out that its use is legal.But this misses the point ndash its use is immoral environmental vandalism.At a time when East Lothian Council has declared a climate emergency, we should be aiming to maximise wildle habitats.We should therefore be cherishing the greenery that surrounds us, not zapping it with toxic chemicals.The use of glyphosate has also been linked to cancer in humans for this and other reasons, other local authorities, and indeed nations, have already pledged not to use it.Under the Nature ConservationAct of , all public bodies are required to further the conservation of bioersity when carrying out their responsibilities and the Scottish Bioersity Strategy makes explicit that local authorities have a key role in preventing habitat loss.We therefore believe that East Lothian Council should lead by example. By stopping sprayingELC can:- Help wildle thrive- Educate residents on the immense ecological benefits of wilder areas and the need to leave behind an outdated obsession with nature looking lsquoneatrsquo- Honour the ideals of John Muir- Help meet its legal duties to bioersity and save money and,- Make our county even more beautul.Now is the perfect opportunity to make this vital change for bioersity.Rewilding East LothianFriends Of The Earth East LothianEast Lothian GreensSustaining North BerwickLower Impact Living CICLove Musselburgh CICEast Linton Melting PotRepair Cafe East LintonClimate FriendlyAberladyBelhaven Community Garden volunteers

title: trademark-quiff-shaved-off-boost-bethany-christian-trust
story: Ezra Bragg, , known as Ez, had his trademark quf chopped off by his we Jen, , in aid of his employer, the Bethany Christian Trust, which has launched a pound, emergency appeal.The head shave took place in the communal garden of their Inveresk Road home, watched by neighbours from a distance.The couple, who have so far raised pound,, said they were ldquototally blown away and humbled by the incredible generosity of family, friends and total strangers.Jen, a psychiatric nurse who has worked in the voluntary sector helping those who suffered from mental health issues and trauma, and survivors of abuse in care, set up a JustGiving page for donations. She said: ldquoItrsquos incredible how people have donated, encouraged and supported Ez going bald for Bethany.Ez has worked with the trust for about  years, initially as a project worker and, for the last four years, as one of two maintenance officers for the charityrsquos homeless units.He said seeing himself in the mirror was strange but he was getting used to his new look.You can see Jen in action shaving Ezrsquos hair on Facebook at shorturl.at nzBILTo donate to Ezrsquos head shave, go to justgiving fundraising jen-braggTo find out more about the Bethany Christian Trustrsquos pound, emergency appeal, visit bethanychristiantrust support-work make-a-donation

title: lockdown-qmu-students-25-000-funding-support
story: Up to  students and student businesses will be able to apply for grants between pound-pound,, awarded by the education initiative Santander Universities UK.Sir Paul Grice, the universityrsquos principal and vice chancellor, has released a video thanking Santander for its generosity.He said: ldquoSantander is a key partner of the university and, indeed, an important part of the QMU community. I want to thank Santander Universities both for their help now, at a time of crisis, but also for their support over many years.Details of how to apply for the grants will be made available to students in the coming weeks.For more than a decade, Santander Universities UK has been supporting QMU with funding to enable its students, staff and graduates access to opportunities ndash including scholarships, internships, mobility grants, entrepreneurial assistance and financial help ndash to ensure they can focus on their studies.When the coronavirus pandemic began to unfold, Santander Universities worked with QMU to reallocate pound, of its funding to support students adversely affected by the situation.This funding has continued to bolster the universityrsquos International Hardship and Student Discretionary Funds, which assist students whose continuing access to education might be placed in jeopardy due to financial dficulties.Santander Universities then recently announced an additional pound, to help support students and student businesses affected by Covid-.To view Sir Paulrsquos video message go to youtu.be rQYWxtajHMg

title: ace-tennis-success-noted-mp-westminster
story: Bryan Leslie, of Gullane Tennis Club, was named Volunteer of the Year, while the East Lothian Open, which takes place in North Berwick, won Competition of the Year at the Tennis Scotland Awards.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, highlighted the success with an Early Day Motion in the House of Commons last month.The motion called on the House of Commons to congratulate those involved while noting ldquothat both winners will go on to be shortlisted for the Lawn Tennis Association awards, covering the whole of Great Britain and [aimed] to celebrate the wonderful contribution of those people and venues through bringing tennis to new people and places from volunteers to officials.

title: proud-owner-eisenhowers-autograph
story: To mark the th anniversary of VE Day amidst the Covid- lockdown, Adrian McDowell, who lives on Promenade, was inspired to to publicly share, through the Musselburgh Courier, the story of a programme signed by General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary Force in Europe.In , General Eisenhower, who went on to become US President, was made a Freeman of the City of Belfast and Mr McDowellrsquos late uncle John, then Assistant Town Clerk of the city, was present at the ceremony.Mr McDowell, acting president of Musselburgh Horticultural Society, said: ldquoMy late uncle John, who retired as Assistant Town Clerk but who was then a young man, asked the general to autograph his copy of the programme and I have it proudly framed.In a twist of fate, Mr McDowell also met American navy top brass when he was Town Clerk in Bangor in .The honourable John H Dalton, US Secretary of the Navy, visited the town in Northern Ireland to see the pier Eisenhower left to go out into Belfast Lough and board the battleship USS Texas ndash part of the Western Bombardment Fleet getting ready to depart for the D Day Normandy landings. Mr Dalton was shown a commemorative plaque by Mr McDowell.Mr McDowell also played host to the late Admiral William J Crowe, who was Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff under President Bill Clinton, when he was US Ambassador to Great Britain.Mr McDowell said: ldquoThe th anniversary of VE Day reminded me of General Dwight D. Eisenhowerrsquos visit to Bangor in May , many years before I was to become Chief Executive and Town Clerk of the Borough.He explained: ldquoBangor Bay had a strategic role in the Normandy Landings ndash Operation Overlord. Many warships lay at anchor under the command of US Rear Admiral Morton L. Deyo.These included the ,-ton battleship Texas together with the US warships Arkansas, Baldwin and Nevada, which had been badly damaged at Pearl Harbor. Royal Navy ships included Bellona, Black Prince, Enterprise and Erebus. French ships included the cruiser Montcalm and the George Leygues.ldquoAltogether, around , men were aboard the ships. They were all part of the Armada under Rear Admiral Kirk, Commander of the Western Naval Task Force which would carry out major bombardment of German Forces overlooking the Normandy beaches.ldquoBallyholme Beach, situated close to Bangor, was used by landing craft preparing for the landings at Omaha and Utah beaches. Across Belfast Lough and nearly opposite Bangor is the town of Carrickfergus, where the US Rangers were based at Sunnylands Camp to receive intensive commando training, as their task was to scale the Pointe du Hoc ndash the height of a -storey building ndash under intense fire.ldquoSo, as the ships were making ready to sail for D-Day on June , General Eisenhower, or lsquoIke,rsquo as he was affectionately known, visited Bangor in May to go on board a number of ships to wish those sailing Godspeed.ldquoWhen the war was over, he was invited to Belfast to be made a Burgess of the City in recognition of his brilliant leadership as Supreme Allied Commander of Allied Expeditionary Forces in Europe.

title: shielding-runner-takes-garden-half-marathon
story: Stephen Ferguson, , who has asthma, decided to undertake the challenge as he is currently lsquoshieldingrsquo for  weeks after receiving advice from the NHS amidst the Covid- pandemic.He is no stranger to half marathons, having completed three in the past ndash Glentress Trail, Edinburgh and, most recently, Stirling.This time round he is planning to take his treadmill outside on June , and hopes to finish his lsquogardenrsquo half marathon ndash . miles ndash in about two hours.He might even attempt the full marathon distance of . miles in four hourshe can raise enough money for First Step, which celebrates its th anniversary this year.Mr Ferguson, who works with the Royal Bank of Scotland in Haddington, lives on Musselburghrsquos Galt Crescent, near First Step in Galt Avenue, and was inspired to take on the fundraising challenge as his three-year-old son Cormac enjoys attending its nursery.He said: ldquoMy we and son also attended baby classes there, so, from when he was a newborn, he has been involved with First Step.ldquoAll the staff there are amazing and it is more like a family than a nursery. My son gets so excited about going there on a daily basis to see his friends and teachers.ldquoI have seen first hand what First Step does for the community. They are a vital asset to Musselburgh and the surrounding areas.Originally from Omagh in Northern Ireland, Mr Ferguson has lived in Scotland since October , and married his we Louise last October.He also has a step daughter, Aaliyah, who is approaching her th birthday.He said: ldquoAt the moment I am shielding for  weeks, as advised to by the NHS.ldquoI felt this would be a good opportunity to do something worthwhile and raise some money for charity. I know a lot of smaller charities may be struggling now so itrsquos a no brainer really.His past half marathons have raised pound for Asthma UK, a charity close to his heart, and pound for Marie Curie because of the care his late aunt received from its nurses.He is being helped with his training by Junior Burton of JB Combat Bootcamp, Wallyford.Mr Ferguson explained: ldquoJunior Burton and JB Combat Bootcamp have supported me through all these events and helped me improve my quality of le through my fitness, which has improved my asthma undoubtedly.ldquoHe has set me up with an online training plan and has given me extra work to do to help with my marathon training.ldquoI have attended Juniorrsquos bootcamp for around five years now.Mr Ferguson has set a fundraising target of pound, adding: ldquoI would love to smash that and raise at least pound,.First Step was set up in  by a group of local parents who wanted somewhere safe and comfortable where they could meet and their children could play.The initiative has developed its services to meet local needs while continuing to be managed by a community-led management committee and employing a staff team to support local families.To donate to Mr Fergusonrsquos challenge, go to justgiving crowdfunding stephen-ferguson-

title: stranded-couple-make-back-home-north-berwick-tenerife
story: Eileen Carmichael, , and her partner Tony Gill, , both of Craigleith View, had arrived in Tenere on January .They were due tohome on March  but paid to get an earlier flight on March .Two days before the flight was due to leave the couple were told it was cancelled. It had been redesignated as a rescue flight and filled with people on package holidays so local hotels could close.Eileen and Tony then booked onto six other flights home, on March , April , April , April , May  and May  ndash all of which were cancelled.Eileen and Tony finally made it home on May  after booking a flight with British Airways through a travel agent.Their flight home left Tenere on May , taking them to Madrid, where they had a two-hour stop, then Heathrow, where they stayed in a hotel overnight, and then on to Edinburgh, the only route home available.A spokesperson for the Foreign Office who saw a story about the stranded couple in a previous issue of the Courier contacted us to offer their help.At first, repeated attempts to contact the Foreign Office by the couple went unanswered.When the couple and the Foreign Office did make contact, Eileen claims the Foreign Office were ldquothree or four days behind flightsrsquo scheduled departure dates and also got layover times mixed up.Eileen said she would have preferred a more direct flight home but accepted that that was not possible.She added: ldquoThere was only one terminal open at Heathrow and people staggered about everywhere ndash it was like a ghost town.ldquoWe didnrsquot have to worry about our luggage during out connecting flights, that was sorted for us, and we just picked it up in Edinburgh.ldquoI feel like airlines shouldnrsquot take bookings when they feel that flight wonrsquot go ahead.Eileen and Tony are delighted to be home, saying ldquoNorth Berwick is wonderful.Eileen added: ldquoItrsquos nice to get out for a walk and speak to people, evenit is socially distanced.ldquoIn Tenere only one person was allowed out, we couldnrsquot even walk to the supermarket together. It was much stricter over there.

title: peregrine-falcons-return-torness-power-station
story: More than  chicks have fledged from the nest site at the power station, to the south-east of Dunbar, in the past  years, with this yearrsquos pair successfully rearing three new chicks.Workers are able to monitor the familyrsquos progress on energy supplier EDFrsquos internal network via a webcam installed in  giving a fascinating insight into how the adults care for their young.Diana Dyce, of the companyrsquos environmental safety group, said: ldquoIrsquom normally able to see the nest through the window from my desk and watching the chicks grow each year is a real highlight.ldquoDuring nesting season this year, though, Irsquove been working from home as we limit the number of people on site to manage the Covid- situation, so the webcam has been crucial for me and others who have wanted to keep an eye on the family.The grounds of the power station offer a safe haven for the birds, where they can nest undisturbed each year.Robert Gunn, station director, said: ldquoAs the only site in East Lothian to hold the Bioersity Benchmark, we actively encourage wildle so itrsquos wonderful to see the peregrinesyear after year.ldquoIrsquom delighted another three chicks look set to fledge from this successful nesting site, bringing the total for the past  years to  chicks.Torness has held the Wildle Trustrsquos Bioersity Benchmark award since  one of four sites in Scotland and the only one in East Lothian to do so.

title: column-providing-support-business-owners
story: If you have a new continuous cough, a fever or anosmia then you should self-isolate for seven days, and members of your household should stay at home for  days.Anosmia is when you have a loss or change in your sense of smell, but it can also affect your taste.Following close monitoring of the data and evidence on Covid-, it has been decided that there are sufficient grounds to include anosmia as an addition to the symptoms list on guidance for staying home.The Scottish Government launched the Covid Business Support Fund Grant Scheme, in order to help businesses get cash support through the coronavirus crisis.In East Lothian, we have seen , applications and , grants awarded to businesses in the constituency, with a value of around pound. million.The grant support is worth approximately pound billion to businesses in Scotland and will be distributed as quickly as possible to ensure businesses have the support they are entitled to.This is undoubtedly an extremely dficult time for businesses, and we need to give them the best possible chances to get through this crisis.If you are a business owner, I would encourage you to look into the support that you can receive at findbusinesssupport.gov.scotYou can also play your part in supporting businesses through this time, by looking to see what local businesses you can buy your essentials from at this time.Many local businesses in Musselburgh can be found on edinburghlockdowneconomy and for finding local food and drink you can look on foodanddrink.scot support-localNot only will using websites like these help local businesses survive through the pandemic, but many are offering safe alternatives to visiting supermarkets, by offering home deliveries and helping you to beat supermarket queues.At this time, more than ever, we must champion our local business owners and producers, and be proud of the products that are made and sold on our doorsteps.

title: civic-week-organisers-planning-special-competitions
story: The town had been due to toast two milestones in its history this summer before coronavirus forced the cancellation of activities across the country.Dunbar Community Council was planning a week-long celebration to mark the th anniversary of the granting of a Burgh Charter to the town by King David II.At the same time, the town was due to hold its th anniversary of Civic Week.George Robertson, who heads the organising committee of Civic Week, told the Courier the anniversaries were ldquotoo important to be missed and instead a trio of competitions had been drawn up.He said: ldquoIt is Eileen Moore [a member of the organising committee] who is really organising the competition.ldquoShe came up with the idea and I think it is a great one.ldquoHopefully, it will lt the spirits of the people in the town when they are in lockdown and getting a bit bored and also mark the occasion.ldquoWe were planning a big event this year that had to go by the board but at least this will give something.Each year, children in Dunbar have the chance to make up the Royal Court, including the Civic Week Queen.This yearrsquos event was due to take place between June  and  and was to feature a iety of events, including the crowning of the Civic Week Queen.However, the entire programme had to be shelved due to the global pandemic.Eileen added: ldquoFamilies are looking for positive and creative activities at this time, something that can be done at home, and something that can keep Civic Week alive for another year.ldquoIt will not be the same as our fun day, but it will be a wonderful chance to show what our wonderful people in Dunbar are capable of.The competition is split into three: best dressed house, best dressed window and best dressed scarecrow.Pictures of homes and windows should be sent to dunbarcivicweek@outlook, with the pictures then shared on social media.The scarecrow should ideally represent any well-known person connected to Dunbar over the past  years, such as Oliver Cromwell, John Muir, Black Agnes, Robert Wilson, General Sir Reginald Wingate or Mary Queen of Scots.All entries should be sent in by pm on June  to email address dunbarcivicweek@outlookFor more details, go to www.dunbarcivicweek.org.uk

title: lockdown-pubs-deliver-1-000-free-meals
story: Jack Robertson took over The Coalgate in Ormiston last year and has been providing the meals alongside his cousin Grant Laurenson, , who owns The Foresters, in PathheadThey have been delivering meals to Tranent and Pencaitland, as well as Ormiston, but people can also collect them from The Coalgate every Thursday, between noon and pm.Jack, , said: ldquoWe just did it off our own back and want to help people that we know who need it.ldquoIrsquom shocked at how many people are struggling for a hot meal itrsquos really upsetting. We want to do what we can while we can.Some of Jackrsquos staff have been coming into work and preparing the meals, while sticking to distancing and health and safety guidelines.They started off with soup and stovies but are now branching out into other foods such as macaroni, with the aim of giving people at least one hearty, home-cooked meal a day.So far, more than , meals have been provided.Jack said: ldquoThe amount of people we have been helping is really good, itrsquos really rewarding.ldquoThe number of meals keeps going up and itrsquos keeping me busy.ldquoI canrsquot believe the response and the number of people getting in touch, but Irsquom still worried we are missing people out thatrsquos my main concern.ldquoThe community has been fantastic and is helping each other out.He has also been dropping off shopping and checking in on people while doing his rounds.Morrisons in Portobello also donated some food items so food parcels could be made for those who are struggling during the ongoing crisis.Anyone who would like to use the service, or recommend someone  who could benefit from it, are asked to message The Coalgate on Facebook at www.facebook thecoalgate or call   on a Wednesday or Thursday.

title: compass-school-pupils-put-colourful-display-chas
story: Children, parents and staff at the Haddington school held a Rainbow Fun Day earlier this month in aid of CHAS .Everyone who took part wore as many bright colours as they could find at home, and sent in photographs to the school, where they were arranged into an impressive gallery of colour.At the same time, families were asked to make a donation in support of the charity, which provides the only hospice care for children with le-shortening conditions across Scotland.Mark Becher, headteacher at the West Road school, thanked everyone for taking part.He said: ldquoWe have been overwhelmed by the support that has been provided to this initiative.ldquoAt this time of crisis, the rainbow has become a symbol of hope and of kindness.ldquoWe felt that to take this theme and to build a fun activity around it in which everyone could become involved and, at the same time, raise essential funds for CHAS would be a great way of bringing the school community lsquotogetherrsquo, even though we are all confined to our homes just now.ldquoWe have been truly amazed by the generosity of our families and friends and are so pleased that we have been able to raise such a signicant amount for such a worthy and important cause.With the spread of Covid-, CHAS is having to overcome additional challenges to provide its usual services in a bid to ensure families are not even more isolated. CHAS is working closely with the NHS to continue to provide end of le care in both Rachel House and Robin House it is also launching the worldrsquos first virtual childrenrsquos hospice to ensure it can continue to support families who are self-isolating as well as keep them and CHAS staff as safe as possible.

title: six-things-need-know-sturgeon-confirms-lockdown-easing-next-week
story: Phase  of the plan will begin from a week today, May .More outdoor activity, meeting other households and plans for the reopening of schools were among the topics discussed.Speaking to the Scottish Parliament, the First Minister said:ldquoI hope they will bring some improvement to peoplersquos wellbeing and quality of le, start to get our economy moving again, and start to steer us safely towards a new normality.ldquoItrsquos important to stress, though, that while the permitted reasons to be out of your house will increase, the default message during phase one will remain lsquoStay at Homersquo as much as possible.Meeting family and friends:The First Minister confirmed today that as of May , your household will nowbe able to meet up with another household outdoors.This will need to be in small groups, including in gardens, but with social distancing required at all times.Under phase , you will not allowed to meet other households indoors - this will come in phase .Sports and outdoor activityThe latest easing of restrictions mean as of May  more outdoor activity will be permitted.This includes sunbathing or sitting in the park, as long as social distancing is maintained.Unrestricted outdoor exercise will continue, with non-contact sport such as golf, hiking, canoeing, outdoor swimming, fishing and bowls all back on the table.ShoppingDrive-thru outlets will be gradually re-opened under the new plans.Garden centres and plant nurseries can also reopen with physical distancing.However cafes should not open at this stage - except for takeaway.SchoolsSchool staff are toto the classrooms from May  - with Nicola Sturgeon confirming all schools in Scotland will reopen from August .The reopening of schools will be ablended model of in-school and at-home learning.From next week, child-minding services can reopen.Transition support will be available for children starting P and S as of next week.WorkAs we move into Phase , remote working remains the "default position" for those who can.For those who have to travel to work, a employers are encouraged to use staggered start times and flexible working.Nicola Sturgeon says she is encouraging employers to lookat the possibility of a -day week as we begin to look at dferent working patterns due to parenting restrictions with the eventual phased reopening of schools.Construction work can also begin to restartas of May .The Scottish Government is also preparing for the safe re-openinbg of the housing market.Pubs RestaurantsUnder the current guidance, pubs and restaurants will not be able to reopen next week.As of phase , which is an unknown date as yet, pubs and restaurants can open their outdoor spaces with physical distancing and increased hygeine routines.Only when we reach phase  will pubs be allowed to open their indoor spaces.Note:Dates for phases - have not yet been set, as the virus "is and will remain unpredictable", accordingto the First Minister.

title: recycling-centres-across-east-lothian-re-open-june-1
story: Facilities in Dunbar, North Berwick, Macmerry and Kinwegar, near Wallyford, have been shut for several weeks.Various conditions have been set out ahead of the re-opening of the four sites in a bid to maintain safety.Councillor Norman Hampshire, the local authorityrsquos spokesman for the environment, said: ldquoAlthough we know that some local residents have experienced inconvenience during these temporary closures, government guidance was clear that a journey to household waste recycling centre was not considered essential travel, so East Lothian Council prioritised maintaining essential kerbside collections which our residents rely on.ldquoThe safety of both staff and site users remains our top priority and in order to reopen we will be introducing new rules following national guidelines around social distancing measures, appropriate hygiene procedures and traffic management and we ask that people planning to come to these sites respect and observe these requirements.Visitors to a recycling centre must:middot Produce proof of East Lothian residency such as driving licence, council tax letter to be shown through your car window to our staff ndash no ID  no access.middot Not travel to any recycling centreyou are showing any signs of infection, have a member of your household showing symptoms, or are self-isolating due to Covid-.middot Be aware of the limit on the number of vehicles allowed onto the tipping areas. This will operate on a one in one out system and will inevitably lead to long queues at peak times.middot Remain at least two metres away from staff and other site users in line with social distancing measures.middot Be physically able to lt and carry anything you bring. Staff at the centres will not be able to assist you with any unloading.middot Make sure only one adult per vehicle should get out of the vehicle to unload and dispose of items.middot Keep all children within your vehicle at all times for their safety and protection.middot Be aware that pedestrian access to the recycling centres is not permitted.middot Note that the last vehicle will be admitted at .pm in line waste management licensing conditions.middot Note there is a temporary limit of five standard household refuse sacks, with either garden waste or domestic waste, or a combination of both not exceeding five sacks can be disposed of per visit.Mr Hampshire added: ldquoInitially the sites will only be able to accept a maximum of five standard sized refuse sacks with garden waste or normal domestic waste and small electrical items for disposal per vehicle.ldquoThis is strictly a temporary measure put in place for everyonersquos benefit to ensure that vehicles can unload quickly, reducing queues and waiting times for everyone , and will be relaxed after the initial expected high demand to access the centres reduces.ldquoIf queues become too long and are deemed to be dangerous we will be forced to close the centres so I would urge you to follow these rules, help speed up the process and give everybody the opportunity to dispose of their material.Refuse sacks can contain domestic waste that would normally go in a green wheelie bin garden waste that would normally go in a brown wheelie bin or small electrical appliances, such as a toaster or kettle.There will be traffic management systems at all recycling centres both inside and on the approach to the centres.Due to the number of residents expected at the recycling centres, queues may quickly form with waiting times so residents are asked to considertheir trip is truly essential.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: ldquoLegally we cannot accept waste after .pm, the gates will be closed at .pm to allow cars already inside the confines of the recycling centre to unload however no cars queuing outside will be admitted onto the site.ldquoAlthough we intend to still accommodate vans and trailers before .am each morning these vehicles must follow the same five standard refuse sack limit amount as cars.ldquoPlease note that for the immediate period after we reopen we cannot accept any construction commercial waste or cardboard on the site.ldquoVehicles carrying commercial waste have other disposal outlets available to them to dispose of their waste legally.

title: communities-cockenzie-port-seton-humbie-east-west-saltoun-bolton-longniddry-musselburgh-prestonpans-offering-support-covid-19
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE Cockenzie and Port Seton Resilience Group continues its service to help those in need but is starting to plan for how the effort can continue once lockdown restrictions are eased.The effort is being led by the local community council, whose chairman Bryan Hickman said: ldquoWersquove been asked to plan the resilience group going forward, how we will help when people go back to work and how we will deliver afterwards.ldquoWersquove got enough volunteers and finances that when people start ing to work we can keep it going for a long time and we can still produce as many meals as we are doing.Bryan said that the Port Seton Centre has had its responder category upgraded, which means all those who wish to enter the centre must now get their temperature checked, in an attempt to ldquotry and improve isolation aspects.The resilience team also received money from the Scottish Government as part of a hardship fund to help those who are struggling, for example, to pay their bills.Bryan stressed that the money does not need to be paid back and is already starting to be used.Anyone who wishes to apply for the confidential service is asked to contact the Port Seton Centre or the emergency phone number.Bryan also thanked Jenner Rutherford, a volunteer who gave up her time to cook meals at the Port Seton Centre four days a week for seven weeks.Jenner has now gone back to work.On VE Day, afternoon tea boxes were handed out and were well received by the community.A pantry at Port Seton Centre is open pm-pm, Monday-Friday for those needing support with food, toiletries or pet food.Those who wish to attend are asked to social distance and wait for a member of staff to assist them.Delivery enquiries can also be made by calling  .Contact detailsThose who require assistance of any kind are asked to call the resilience emergency number on  .East Saltoun. Picture: Google MapsHumbie, East and West Saltoun, and BoltonA WEEKLY shop is being carried out for those needing assistance in West Saltoun.Residents are doing what they can to help each other, following the establishment of community resilience groups in the village and neighbouring East Saltoun, Humbie and Bolton.Derek Smith, the point of contact in West Saltoun, said they were continuing to do what they could to help one another during the coronavirus pandemic.He said: ldquoAs far as I am aware, we are all coping and doing what we can for our communities as and when there is a need."There is a weekly shop done here for a number of households in West Saltoun.ldquoThe fire brigade are delivering some leaflets just with advice and what not, and they will be distributed as well.ldquoThe other villages are responding to the needs that are being flagged up, whether that be in East Saltoun, Bolton or Humbie.ldquoHumbie are fortunate in that they have the Humbie Hub, and East Saltoun also have The Bothy.ldquoAl Beck [treasurer of Humbie, East and West Saltoun and Bolton Community Council] keeps us all informed about all the information that comes through, plus we get regular updates from the council and they can be passed on as well.ldquoIn a village like West Saltoun, we are pretty self sufficient and we all look out for each other.Contact detailsPeople in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email at shenajamieson@aol.East Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahoo.In West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmail.In Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailLongniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryTHE resilience effort in Longniddry is being led by the local church and supported by Longniddry Community Council.As well as this service, residents have also taken it upon themselves to help friends and neighbours in need.Sheila Jamieson, who is at the heart of the resilience efforts,says requests to her have so far been low but there are about  volunteers ready and willing to carry out enquiries when they come in.One is offering a dog walking service and, while help with shopping can be provided, residents are said to increasingly be getting their shopping delivered to them.Help picking up prescriptions can also be offered but the local pharmacy has a delivery service in place to those aged  and over.Contact detailsAnyone who requires assistance or has a query they would like answered can call Sheila Jamieson on  .Musselburgh. Picture: Google MapsMusselburghMEASURES to help vulnerable residents cope with social isolation during the Covid- pandemic was high on Resilient Musselburghrsquos agenda this week ndash designated as Mental Health Awareness Week by the Mental Health Foundation.Iain Clark, chairman of Musselburgh Area Partnership, said: ldquoWe have implemented several ideas to support mental health wellbeing during the y period of isolation being experienced by many during this crisis.He added: ldquoWe are collaborating with the Courier to source and distribute copies of the newspaper into the community for the over-s so they can take advantage of the additional content of crosswords, puzzles and word searches.ldquoResilient Musselburghrsquos Connected Communities staff have also been working hard to prepare activity packs aimed at both adults and children.ldquoHopefully, these packs will provide some activity to give members of the community an additional focus.The teamrsquos new base at Musselburgh East Community Learning Centre is working well, as the -strong band of volunteers continue to support the communities of Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig and Old Craighall.Iain said: ldquoTo date, we have supported the community through a needs-based distribution of , meals, , soup and sandwiches,  pre-school lunches,  emergency food packs and delivered  prescriptions.He paid tribute to all the volunteers, adding: ldquoWithout their support we would not be able to deliver this support into our community."They continue to deliver a vital response to our community."Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansTHE work of the Prestonpans resilience team continues to grow as more people needing support get in touch with them ndash and they are preparing for additional challenges as the Scottish Governmentrsquos ldquotest, trace isolate, support strategy is introduced.Community council chairman Brian Weddell says the team are aware more people could find themselves self-isolating or shielding as plans to ease the lockdown move forward.He said regular shopping deliveries and dog-walking assistance are being provided by volunteers, with evening grocery collections from local convenience stores now added to the growing list of tasks.He said: ldquoNo job seems too dficult or onerous for our volunteers and we are so grateful for them coming forward and giving up their spare time to help local people in their time of need.ldquoThe next phase of the Scottish Government testing, tracing and isolating strategy could see many people shielding who will require support and we will gear up as this evolves.Residents needing shopping can call upon the three local Scotmid stores in Prestonpans, which have introduced a home-delivery service utilising the resilience volunteers.Anyone needing shopping delivered can contact their nearest Scotmid store.The work at the Pennypit Pantry also continues to grow and last week they provided , meals to local people, along with supplies of groceries and essential household items.The staff at the Pennypit have been contacted by many local people thanking them for their support.If anyone in Prestonpans is needing support with meals or essential groceries, Fundamental Foods can be contacted on   or by email via lornabellany@gmailThe community council is giving special thanks to Jane Russell and her team who are providing fresh Sunday roast chicken dinners, as featured in the Courier.Last weekend, they delivered  meals around East Lothian, and say that their number of elderly referrals has increased during the last few weeks.Visit East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinners on Facebook at www.facebook eastboxes  or call  .Prestonpans Community Council have also set up a hardship fund for people finding it dficult the longer lockdown continues.Contact detailsAnyone needing support should telephone the resilience hotline telephone number on   or email prestonpansresilience@gmail

title: communities-dirleton-dunbar-dunpender-east-lammermuir-gullane-north-berwick-offering-support-covid-19
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonWORKS of art are brightening up an old phonebox in the heart of Dirleton.The Dirleton Area Resilience Teamhave created a number of initiatives to help people throughout the village.Kate Hamer, DART coordinator, has launched the D-ART Gallery where children of primary school age have been creating works of art.The childrenrsquos work will go towards their Hi Award, which records and recognises wider achievement in youngsters, and has been very well received in the village.The phonebox was bought by the community for pound from BT earlier this year and will be transformed into a book exchange once the coronavirus pandemic is over.Other initiatives in the village include the Essentials Larder, with the number of people using the service continuing to grow.David Tait, DARTrsquos lead coordinator, was pleased to see the scheme proving a great success.He said: ldquoThis demonstrates the value of this resource to the community.ldquoWe continue to receive generous donations ndash particular thanks must be given to Lucy Miller of Ferrygate Farm for another generous donation of fresh eggs, and to Ross McGregor and his team at Archerfield Walled Garden for continued donations of flowers, fresh herbs, confectionery and other food items.The larder is now storing baked and cooked goods, including desserts, cakes, crumbles and soups generously prepared and donated by local residents.David added: ldquoSpecial thanks must also go to Andy Gordon of Gordonrsquos Consulting for the generous donation of medical grade KN face masks.ldquoThese will increase the protection DART can offer to the community and our volunteers. Additional masks will be donated to carers within our area.Meanwhile, Janice MacLeod, DART area co-ordinator, has started a new initiative of Wednesday lockdown treats.Assisted by other volunteers, she will be preparing these on a fortnightly basis.They could include fresh meals, desserts and other items.If any resident is interested, they are invited to email Dart.Coordinators@outlook, marking their message for Janicersquos attention.Finally, David is confident that DART will still continue to meet the demands and expectations of the community, and forward planning to meet likely future outcomes will continue to take place.DARTrsquos primary objective remains service to the community, both in the village itself and in the surrounding area.He also notes that, under the new government guidelines, DART is recognised as a third sector organisation and that all volunteers and family members in their household are eligible for Covid- testing.Any DART volunteer showing symptoms can now book a test through the Government website.Contact detailsFor more information, email dart.coordinators@outlookDunbarDunbarDELICIOUS hot meals continue to be delivered to people in need throughout Dunbar.Hundreds of meals are being sent out to those in need throughout the town, as well as East Linton and other surrounding villages.George Robertson, who is heading up the community resilience efforts in Dunbar and West Barns, said it was a service which had proven very well received.He said: ldquoIt is a service that is by referral only and we are trying to get it to the people who need it.ldquoThat has been very, very well received across the ward and includes the East Lammermuir area and as far as East Linton.George praised the efforts of Helen Harper, who is based in Dunbarrsquos Bleachingfield Centre, and Katie Pollock, from Home-Start East Lothian, in getting the project up and running.Catering company Thomas Franks, which operates in Belhaven Hill School, has been at the heart of cooking the meals in Musselburghrsquos Loretto School, before the meals are transported back to Dunbar for distribution.George was confident that the service, which sees almost  meals sent out each week, would continue evenyoungsters ed to school.He added: ldquoIt is very well received from the people that are getting it and they appreciate that.ldquoObviously, there are other ways to get food to people and Dunbarrsquos foodbank has been busy.ldquoThey are distributing food to people to cook themselves and that is just as important to encourage people to do their own cooking.The hot meal group also marked VE Day, with an afternoon tea sent out to elderly members of the community.The townrsquos resilience efforts are split into nine clusters, with each having a lead volunteer.The nine clusters are: Shore and Harbour Group High Street, Parsonspool to Kings Court West End to Countess Road Belhaven and Kirk Park West Barns and the Beveridge Row development Queenrsquos Road and the new housing developments Hallhill, Kellie Road and to the railway line Brodie Road east and north to the railway line and Brodie Road west and north to the railway line.The community councillor said a surprise ndash socially distanced ndash birthday party was being arranged for a resident, with cake and candles being planned.Contact detailsFor more information, go to Dunbar and District Coronavirus Community Helpers atfacebook groups or Dunbar Community Council atfacebook Dunbar CommunityCouncilEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsDunpenderVOLUNTEERS continue to be on hand to help those who need assistance in East Linton and surrounding villages.The Dunpender Community Resilience Team is offering a range of services to people in need in East Linton, Whitekirk, Tyninghame and surrounding areas during the coronavirus crisis.Judith Priest, chairwoman of Dunpender Community Council, said little had changed but services such as shopping and prescription collection continued to be on offer to those who needed it.Contact detailsInformation relating to the coronavirus is available on the Tyninghame Village Hall website ndash www.tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk ndash as well as at www.eastlintonuk People can also contact   or  .Stenton.kim traynor and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.East LammermuirTHE efforts of people supporting each other in four rural villages have been praised.Volunteers have come forward in Spott, Stenton, Innerwick and Oldhamstocks to help any of their neighbours in need.A leaflet was previously sent out to residents highlighting which local businesses did deliveries and how people could get in touch with them.At the same time, shopping collection and prescription pickup services have been on offer in the area.Chris Bruce, chairman of East Lammermuir Community Council, said there were plenty of people ready to help their neighbours where necessary.He said: ldquoYou see people buzzing about in hi-vis gilets doing volunteer work and you see people not wearing hi-vis vests who are obviously helping their neighbours as well.ldquoIt feels, perhaps, dferent but there is a sense in which everybody could have thought, lsquoWe do not need to do anything formal and set up a volunteer system because it is all in hand because we know our neighboursrsquo.ldquoBut the fact people did both and we got  volunteers in each of the villages ndash and we put a cap on that and have a waiting list ndash that was a great endorsement, with people looking to go the extra mile.Contact detailsMore information on the help available to people in the East Lammermuir area is available from the grouprsquos website, www.eastlammermuircommunitycouncil.org.uk.Gullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneTHE Gullane resilience team received a delivery of Mungoswells Malt  Millings bread flour, which was put into .kg bags and made available to residents for pound. per bag.These were collected from the village hall hub on Tuesday, where buyers were encouraged to take care in exercising social distancing and to wear face masks.Also on offer on Tuesday was the toys, books, games, DVD and jigsaw exchange, along with craft packs for the villagersquos children, which this week were based on paper plate creations.The team are asking for donations of duvet covers and sheets to make scrub bags, scrubs and masks for healthcare workers.There is some fabric, instructions and elastic available to those who would like to make masks.Some fabric masks, made by Gullane Scrubbers, are available for a donation to the East Lothian Foodbank.The village has been ided into seven lsquozonesrsquo to co-ordinate support for those who may need help.Each zone has a lead co-ordinator and the -plus volunteers have been allocated across the seven zones.Village co-ordinators are Gordon McLelland and Lorna Scott. Zone lead volunteers are: Andy MurrayAnn PinkertonGordon WoodDebbie SpensRobert OrsquoRiordanClaire Walkerand Clare Tulloch .A map of the zones can be found at www.gullanert CoVid- Contact detailsFor
